Single Grid Search for FastKernelSurvivalSVM

Source: R/tune.R
tune_fastsvm.Rd

Executes a grid search to optimize hyperparameters for a single kernel configuration. Uses cross-validation to evaluate the C-index.

tune_fastsvm(
  data,
  time_col = "t",
  delta_col = "delta",
  param_grid,
  cv = 5L,
  cores = parallel::detectCores(),
  verbose = 0L,
  refit = TRUE,
  ...
)

Arguments

data

Training data frame.

time_col

Time column name.

delta_col

Event column name.

param_grid

A named list (or list of lists) of parameters to tune. Example: list(alpha = c(0.1, 1), rank_ratio = c(0, 1)).

cv

Number of folds (default 5).

cores

Number of parallel cores (default: parallel::detectCores()).

verbose

Verbosity level (0 or 1).

refit

Logical. If TRUE, refit model with best params on full data.

...

Additional fixed parameters passed to all estimators.

Value

An object of class "fastsvm_grid" containing:

  • best_params: A named list of optimal parameters.

  • best_score: The best mean cross-validated C-index.

  • cv_results: A data frame summarizing the search history.

  • best_estimator: The fitted model object (if refit=TRUE).

Parallelization Strategy

The cores argument controls how computation is distributed:

  • Standard Kernels ("rbf", "linear", etc.): If the kernel is a string, the function uses Python's `GridSearchCV` native parallelism (via `joblib`). This is extremely fast and efficient.

  • Custom R Kernels: If the kernel is an R function, `scikit-learn` cannot parallelize natively (pickle error). In this case, the function automatically detects it and uses the mirai package to distribute grid candidates across parallel R workers. Each worker runs cross-validation for one candidate serially.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
if (reticulate::py_module_available("sksurv") && requireNamespace("mirai", quietly = TRUE)) {
  library(FastSurvivalSVM)
  
  # --- Data Generation ---
  set.seed(42)
  df <- data_generation(n = 200, prop_cen = 0.3)

  # =========================================================================
  # CASE 1: Standard Kernel (RBF) - Uses Python Parallelism
  # =========================================================================
  # We want to tune 'alpha' and the RBF 'gamma' parameter.
  
  grid_rbf <- list(
    kernel = "rbf",
    alpha  = c(0.01, 1, 10),
    gamma  = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.1)
  )
  
  res_rbf <- tune_fastsvm(
    data = df, 
    time_col = "tempo", delta_col = "cens",
    param_grid = grid_rbf,
    cv = 3, 
    cores = 2, # Passed to Python's joblib
    verbose = 1
  )
  print(res_rbf)

  # =========================================================================
  # CASE 2: Custom Kernel in R - Uses mirai Parallelism
  # =========================================================================
  
  # 1. Define a Kernel Factory (e.g., simple Sum-Product kernel)
  make_sumprod <- function(bias = 0) { 
    force(bias)
    function(x, z) {
      prod(as.numeric(x) * as.numeric(z)) + bias
    }
  }
  
  # 2. Create variants to tune the 'bias' parameter
  #    This creates a list of functions with metadata
  k_variants <- create_kernel_variants(make_sumprod, bias = c(0, 1, 5))
  
  # 3. Define grid
  grid_custom <- list(
    kernel = k_variants,   # The kernel function itself is a parameter
    alpha  = c(0.1, 1)     # Standard regularization
  )
  
  # 4. Tune (Automatically detects custom kernel -> switches to mirai)
  res_custom <- tune_fastsvm(
    data = df, 
    time_col = "tempo", delta_col = "cens",
    param_grid = grid_custom,
    cv = 3, 
    cores = 2, # Starts 2 background R daemons
    verbose = 1
  )
  print(res_custom)
}
} # }
